raw_text:
French honour for director Parker
 
 British film director Sir Alan Parker has been made an officer in the Order of Arts and Letters, one of France's highest cultural honours.
 
 Sir Alan received his decoration in Paris on Wednesday from French Culture Minister Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres. "You have explored the possibilities of film with an immense talent," Mr de Vabres said as he presented the award. Parker praised French films, saying: "Hollywood, which created modern cinema, uses it only as a commodity." He told the minister: "I am honoured to be thus distinguished by France, the flag carrier of cinema throughout the world." Sir Alan's films include Oscar-winning Fame plus Midnight Express and The Commitments.
 
 A founding member of the Director's Guild of Great Britain, he is a former chairman of the UK Film Council and on the board of the British Film Institute. "Through your work and your campaigns, you have shown us how the artist occupies an essential place in our contemporary society," Mr de Vabres said. "Through your dreams which you show us, through the links that you weave, you question the world through the mirror of your work." He also cited the director's 2003 film The Life of David Gale, in which Kevin Spacey played a man on Death Row, as proof of his "veritable artistic commitment against the death sentence".

He received the award from French Culture Minister Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres in Paris. Parker praised French films, saying Hollywood uses them only as a commodity. He also cited The Life of David Gale, which he directed, as an example of his artistic commitment against death.

qwen2.5:3b: British film director Sir Alan Parker has been made an Officer in the Order of Arts and Letters by French Culture Minister Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres. Parker praised French cinema's importance to modern cinema while criticizing Hollywood's use of films as commodities. He is known for works such as Oscar-winning "Fame", "Midnight Express", and "The Commitments". As a founding member of the Director's Guild of Great Britain, he was also chairman of the UK Film Council and on the board of the British Film Institute. De Vabres praised Parker’s artistic contributions and his commitment to opposing capital punishment through films like "The Life of David Gale".

The first part mentions that the award goes to a British film director named Sir Alan Parker. He's from France, so he gets an order honorifically. The Minister presented him in Paris on Wednesday.

Parker spoke to the minister about his talent in film and how Hollywood uses films as a commodity. He compared modern cinema to the gold standard of cinema worldwide. He also praised his films like Fame Plus Midnight Express and The Commitments, which won several Oscars.

He's a founding member of the Director's Guild of Great Britain and former chairman of the UK Film Council, serving on the British Film Institute board. His work includes a 2003 film about David Gale where Kevin Spacey played on Death Row.

Parker also highlighted his artistic commitment against the death penalty through his films. He said his work challenges society through his films.

I need to capture all these key points in a concise summary without adding any extra information or explanations.
</think>

Sir Alan Parker, a British film director from France, has been awarded an Order of Arts and Letters by French Culture Minister Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres. He received the decoration on Wednesday in Paris. Parker praised modern cinema as a commodity while highlighting his films like Fame Plus Midnight Express and The Commitments, which won several Oscars. As founder of the Director's Guild of Great Britain and former chairman of the UK Film Council, he also served as member of the British Film Institute board. His 2003 film about David Gale further underscored his commitment to challenging societal issues through his work.

granite3.1-dense:2b: British filmmaker Sir Alan Parker was appointed an officer in France's Order of Arts and Letters by Culture Minister Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres. During the ceremony, Parker expressed admiration for French cinema, contrasting Hollywood's commodification of film with France's role as a global cinematic pioneer. Known for films like Fame, Midnight Express, and The Commitments (winning an Oscar), Parker also holds significant positions in British film organizations, including founding the Director's Guild of Great Britain and serving as its chairman. Minister de Vabres praised Parker for his crucial role in contemporary society, emphasizing how his work questions societal issues through artistic storytelling. The minister highlighted Parker's 2003 film, The Life of David Gale, as an example of his commitment to challenging the death penalty.
